title: Why are people suprised when they get reported for saying "Easy" after a game?
body:
Honestly, last game I had 3 in my team who couldnt resist to verbally spit the enemy team in the face after we won and when I said I report this insulting, they were seriously suprised... 

Thats like being suprised when someones mad after you spit them in the face after a football game you won...

I don't understand why people defend it. Saying ggez only has the intent of pissing off other players, with the rare use of being the team who got stomped.

FFS IT ONLY PISSES OFF PEOPLE WHO _MAKE_ IT PISS THEM OFF!!

Your not playing in the Champions league or LCS. The four letters (MAX) is only on the screen for less then 3 seconds. It's like you people are _trying_ to find something to nitpick at.
You never answered the question, why say it in the first place?

Excuse me oh wise one. Let me delve into the depts of the english language to find the meaning and purpose of every god damn word.

Nah I don't do that crap. This is how it basically goes

_winning enemy team_: GGEZ

_Me_:  I wonder what's for dinner

_losing enemy team_: GGEZ

_Me_: I wonder what's for dinner

Both scenerios I'm completely indifferent to the four flipping letters because the meaning and impact is kinda dependent on the person recieving the message. For the last fucking time GGEZ is not even 1/10000 times as bad as spiting in someones face. This hyperbole is bullshit and drastically inflates the actually weight of the letters. 

Spitting in someones face is on par with an animal marking another animal territory. You invade their personal space and try to assert your dominace while belittling the other person.

GGEZ is the same as saying 'no sweat'. Or something along those lines. Sometimes I'm pretty sure the other person the other person doesn't even realize their doing it or even is expecting a reaction.

Now riddle me this. Why is it that you are so hell bent on witch hunting for people who say GGEZ when 5 different taunts exist as _features_ in the game. Don't give me that shit about the mastery emote being to show off _your_ skills. If that was the case riot would have let the ability to see enemy materies before a match remain or remove the ability to taunt your opponent with a emote flash every-single-time-you-kill-them.

Why would riot give a champ a joke that calls people noobs {{champion:84}}. Why can you make an audible laugh at your opponents and why can you dance on their corpse?

Then some people wonder why feeders and _actual_ toxic people are dodging the system while people are reporting for GGEZ. 

Priorities amiright?

EDIT: You still have managed to avoid answering the question:

For what purpose would somebody say "ggez" to an opponent after beating them?

In Riot's case: Their focus right now is making the feeder detection system better. They try very hard to deal with all forms of toxic behavior. Some are easier to punish than others, and some are more often reported than others. GGEZ is more likely to be punished if it is in conjunction with other negative behaviors.

I really hope we never meet in a match ever because frankly, you sound like you'd report me for getting tower dived and then that would just be another worthless report that bogs down the system and gives you a lighter report weight.

Now to equate GGEZ to something I would do that with the current downvote system. It's like when you are having a conversation with someone after a thread loses popularity and they continually downvote you. Words are the medium of ideas and emotion by which they are transferred from person to person. I don't report minor things, but harassment isn't minor.

This argument is now finished. To explain why recall your comment on the taunting system:

>Personally I don't think taunts should exist. Unsportsmanlike behavior detracts from the fun of the game. And I agree it is very tilting for some people. It's not fair to those people to allow others to taunt them or harass them after a mistake with emotes.


This is an ideal of yours that I am strongly opposed to. Taunts have been in games for ever whether it be player made or coded in by developers. You believe that taunts are toxic. I just think it adds a new dynamic to a game in a way. A way to show off. People actually _do_ like taunts as surprising as it may seem. 

An example is Smash. Every character has a taunt when you pull off a sick kill then persons will normally taunt. This is the same for if they are bodying you. No one really finds taunts toxic 'unless relentlessy spammed' but even then they do suck it up to an extent. They don't ban that person. That person just gets punished every time they do taunt at a bad time and taunted back at when _they_ get taunted. There is also the fact that as smash evolved characters got _more_ taunts.

The reason why I'm defending people who say GGEZ (I mean from punishments. People will have their own opinions about them) is because I can't agree with punishing for this when people can taunt in other ways.

You can say that it's the intent or meaning behind it that you are opposing but in reality it's the same intent/meaning that is behind many _many_ Ctrl 1/2/3/4/6s. So banning for GGEZ is the same as banning for /dance, /taunt etc in my eyes.

So I'm guessing we'll just have to agree that we disagree.
It doesn't matter, whether or not it actually pisses them off. It has the _intent_.
So you want people to teabag you in those games?
Why would people care about being teabagged?

it's a mild offense but it rings social alarm bells.  When someone teabags, the message usually implies, "look at how much bigger and better my  crotch is than you"

it's a minor thing, but think of a cartoon or even a real life person. If they do a victory dance where they shake their butt or groin in a player's face, it's not good sportsmanship
so... why isnt this in the Player Behavior section? it seems very fit for that section

I'm simply responding to a post that certain things are not "merely" what they are (GGEZ is not just letters - its a specific phrase that sad little people state to make themselves feel better because they are better at a video game) and that "telling the truth" isnt a defense to toxic behavior.

>and that "telling the truth" isnt a defense to toxic behavior.

You surely pull those phrases out of your hat.

you'd be surprised, where they think that it is without consequence just because it can be said.  "I'm just saying the truth"  as one example points to how easily players devalue other players.  To them it is "just" the truth and not additionally an insult, uninformative slander against the opposing team and finally does not take into account that their own team might have just had more experienced and better coordinating players in a completely randomized matchup

Well to your "It's just four letters." comment.. Michelle Carter (the young girl who sent texts to her boyfriend telling him to kill himself when he was severely depressed) was just text messages made up of letters on a screen. Now that's an extreme example, of course, but regardless, words have weight to some people. Regardless of whether it is the truth or not that the game was easy - there is the idea of being decent human being. "GG easy," is rarely said in the simple, honest way in which you describe it as simply telling the truth. It is usually said with venom behind it and is said to put people down. "GG easy," is never something that needs to be said and  typically only upsets people (So why do it?). The only reason behind saying it that I can see is to purposely upset people and/or in some messed up way in which the offender is trying to build themself up by tearing another down.
